metadata.sermon_start_end: The degree of thirst suffered by crucified victims must have been indescribable. This is one of many aspects of crucifixion that we of the affluent "first world" are not able to imagine, since very few of us have ever experienced extreme thirst. John's Gospel records that our Lord [...] The One from whose being flows the gift of the water of eternal life - this is the One who is dying of a terrible thirst on the Cross for the love of his lost sheep.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon focuses on the Johannine 'I thirst'. It correctly identifies the specific Johannine emphasis on sovereignty and fulfillment of Scripture rather than mere human suffering. However, it drifts into a general survey of water in the Bible and Psalm 22, losing the 'nowhere else' specificity of the hyssop and the vinegar bowl.
quotes: John's purpose is different. Each of the three sayings from the Cross in John's Gospel shows Jesus in command
In John's Gospel, therefore, when the Lord Jesus says 'I thirst,' he is speaking in this case not from his very real mortal weakness, but from his sovereign control of his own mission.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Focus more on why this specific text mentions the 'bowl of vinegar' and 'hyssop' in relation to the thirst, rather than retreating to general themes of water in the Old Testament.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: The preacher mentions the Greek 'oxos' and acknowledges scholarly debate, which aligns with Dekker's requirement for academic rigor. However, the exegesis remains on the surface of the text's placement in the Johannine narrative without deep historical-critical engagement with the 'hyssop' or the specific 'finished' (tetelestai) logic.
quotes: It is very difficult to tell what exactly was intended by the offering of vinegary wine (oxos) to Jesus.
Scholars who have studied this thoroughly have not been able to come to any firm conclusion.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Move beyond 'scholars have not been able to conclude' to a more decisive theological exposition of the specific elements (like hyssop) in the context of Israel's history (Passover).

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is extremely weak. Aside from a brief mention of the 'affluent first world' at the start, there is no concrete application to the contemporary zeitgeist, politics, or the specific spiritual misery of the modern hearer. It remains a 'speech about the gospel' rather than an application to the hearer's life.
quotes: This is one of many aspects of crucifixion that we of the affluent 'first world' are not able to imagine
This three-hour service offers us the opportunity to approach it in solemn contemplation.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Connect the 'thirst' of Christ to the specific 'thirsts' or 'lostness' of the modern congregation. What does this sovereign thirst say to a society that seeks satisfaction in everything but the 'living water'?

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon is structured as a lecture. It explains the text, then looks back at other texts, then concludes with a 'reflection'. The hearer is an observer of the text's meaning rather than being 'expounded' by the text itself.
quotes: Now, having noted the lofty purpose of John's Gospel, we may pause to think about the thirst itself.
Reflect now upon the saying from the Cross...
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Avoid phrases like 'let us look back' or 'reflect now'. Instead, bring the reality of the text directly into the present reality of the hearer throughout the exposition.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: Redemption is central (the self-offering of the Good Shepherd), but misery is treated as a physical sensation (thirst) rather than the theological 'misery before God'. Gratitude is implied but not developed as a response of the subject.
quotes: The Crucifixion is not an accident... It is the deliberate self-offering of the Good Shepherd.
this is the One who is dying of a terrible thirst on the Cross for the love of his lost sheep.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Deepen the 'misery' aspect. The thirst of Christ should expose the spiritual dehydration and 'lostness' of the hearer.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The 'two ways' are almost entirely absent. There is a mention of 'lost sheep', but no sense of the urgency of choice or the possibility of being lost (temporal or eternal). The tone is one of 'solemn contemplation' rather than a call to a destination.
quotes: for the love of his lost sheep.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: The preacher must address the consequence of refusing the 'living water'. If Christ thirsts to fulfill the plan, what is the destination of the hearer who ignores this fulfillment?

7_christocentric_grace.findings: This is the strongest point. The sermon is explicitly Christocentric, emphasizing the two natures (Word made flesh) and Christ as the sovereign Lord of his own death. Christ is clearly the telos.
quotes: This is the Son of God speaking, the Second Person of the Blessed Trinity.
Jesus Christ, therefore - the Word made flesh - is the same One who commands living water
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Ensure that this Christology leads to a concrete word of grace that detaches the hearer from themselves, rather than just providing a 'staggering' thought to absorb.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 11-12 minutes, the sermon fails Dekker's 20-minute minimum. It lacks the 'breadth' required for true 'depth'. It functions more as a 'meditation' (as the title suggests) than a full sermon.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the application and the connection to the zeitgeist to reach the necessary breadth for a full sermon.

overall_assessment.summary: The text falls short of being a sermon according to Dekkerâ€™s definition; it is a theological meditation. It lacks the required length (under 20 minutes) and fails significantly in concrete application and the 'two ways'. While the Christological focus is strong and the distinction of the Johannine voice is clear, it remains too objective and detached from the hearer's contemporary reality.
strengths: Strong Christological focus on the sovereignty of Christ (Thesis 7).
Clear distinction of the specific Johannine witness compared to the Synoptics (Thesis 1).
weaknesses: Absence of the 'two ways' and the seriousness of human responsibility (Thesis 6).
The structure is too much like a lecture/meditation and not an interwoven proclamation (Thesis 4).
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is not a sermon in the Dekkerian sense. It is an adequate theological meditation, but it lacks the 'breadth' for depth and the 'concreteness' of application that constitutes a true proclamatory word.
